Bottle. Pours a clear and amber with a yellow hue. Big lacing, off white and very creamy head. Aroma is sweet and malty with a breadlike feel. High carbonation. Dry mouthfeel. Flavour is not as sweet as the aroma. No traces of the alcohol, but with a warming feel. I kind of like it!

Pour is a clean looking brown with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is drffinatly bready malts and lots of it.  Flavor is a bit weak and watery.  Some caramel malts and i agreee with a lot of raters here that the alcohol is quite potent in this one.  Will have to have others of its kind to compare it to but this is a average at best beer.

Green bottle.  Aroma of caramel malt with slight grape and alcohol.  Sweet with some orange.  Pale, clear orange body with a orange-tinged rocky beige head.  Good deal of malt in the taste and a somewhat high level booziness.  Slightly sour and salty, a little funky.  Medium bitterness on an oily medium body.  Some sticky caramel.  Warming dry, sticky aftertaste.  Much more complex than most members of the style, but the booziness is a big turnoff.
Bottle. Amber colour with a huge off white head. Rich aroma and taste of malts and fruit. Good bock.
A malty, caramely beer.  I am not sure I remember this beer so much as I remember what I would rate it. It was a rough night.

Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Light amber colour. Powerfull malty/hoppy aroma. Really great. Powerfull bitter flavor. Lots of licoricenotes. Long bitter finish. Creamy palate. Great beer.
Draft.  Some aroma of sweet malt and a little bubblegum.  Flavor is pretty much the same with a dry finish.  Good amount of flavor for a lager.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2007 (Rerate; bumped it up a bit) Draft; orange amber with a medium white head.  Pretty good balance of flavor.  Dry finish; some malt, hops, and breadiness.  Pretty good beer, for a style im not overly familiar with.

Bottle.  Clear copper-orange in color with a small beige head that doesnt last long.   Very light aroma of  malt and faint hops.  Flavor is much bolder, but smooth bock lager, quickly transitioning to a hoppy bitter finish.  Not a style I like, though it is obviously a well made brew.  Fairly drinkable.  I never once noticed the alcohol and that is remarkable since its a high abv brew and I look for and appreciate an alcohol bite in most brews.   Good, but I enjoyed the kindl weisse more.

This is a fantastic maibock, amber in color with an orange hue, big & fluffy light tan head, aroma full of malts with hints of caramel, toffee & pine, velvetty-smooth body, very drinkable, lots of malt in the flavors with subtle notes of caramel, herbs & nuts, but its really the finish & aftertaste that makes this beer so great, very smooth, begs you to take another gulp, this is borderline addicting, very impressive beer

mild malty nose with a few esters. Nice copper red with some head and lace. From 12 oz bottles that just arrived at Bodega Brew Pub, downtown La Crosse, Wisconsin USA. Well carbonated, ( just a tad too much for my taste), dryish, maltly and a bit boozy. Easy to drink, but maybe a bit too easy with the strength.

Copper, significantly darker than the other maibock I recently had. Im really liking the complexity of maibocks, this one has fruity sweetness, berries, herbs. Lightly bitter on hops. Very nice. A little smooth on the carbonation maybe.

The aroma is malty with yeast, mild hops, and butter. The appearance is copper/amber with two finger head. The flavor is malty with butterscotch and herbal bitter hops. The palate is thin but smooth. The aftertaste is sweet and somewhat toasty. Overall this is quite a unique taste for me.
Bottle.  Strong smell, a little too strong. Smells and tastes  a little too sweet though still very drinkable and goes down smooth.

I had this beer on draft at the Old German Beer Hall in Milwaukee.  The overly sweet maltiness was not really for me, and it is significantly sweeter than other maibocks Ive had (Summit in recent memory).  Blasphemy I know, but I really preferred the Kindl Weisse.

Appearance was a sparkling mahogany brown in a dimpled mug with good head formation.  Aroma and flavor were both quite sweet.  Mouthfeel was slightly sticky.  This beer was rather drinkable.
Foamy and a beige body. Malty and some hoppy aroma. Easy drinking, a light bitter well malted. Understated carbonation though present. A good example of the style
Bought a bottle at Matignettis in Brighton. Copper color. Malty taste with a long lasting after taste. Spicy and sweeter than most beers.

A light amber color.  Did not have a dark organish color as others have indicated.  Has a medium white head but suprising little carbonation.  Has a citrus taste to it that doesnt disappoint and is suprisingly light.  A tinge of alcohol is noticeable at the finish, but overall is a pleasant experience.  I could drink this one all night and not notice the almost 8% alcohol by volume.

Strong lactic sour milk aroma on initial pouring. Bronze amber colour. Bitterness and sourness from lactic lasting through the malty breadiness. Not particularly pleasant perhaps a bad bottle. Dry finish. Not sure of alcohol not given on bottle.

Picked up a bottle of this from an off-license off Landsberger strasse, München, Germany.  Felt inspired after a first time at the Hofbräu, took this one back to our hostel and downed it just before I rid myself of the pent up aromatics of the day at hand, ahem, took a shower.Produced itself a bright, shimmering copper in the glass, tawny in the depths. The head rose and fell quickly as my glass was in desperate need of a clean. I guess it would have presented well as the carbonation seemed minute and slow to release. Aroma seemed fruity, dominantly fruity - which is not the prerequisite of the style - though a dark honey, tree-bark and dusted, toasted malt addition made this sumptuous. It repeats in the mouth, quite sweet, heavily toasted and honeyish with evident herbal hops in back. Body is medium, its not robust though it has good presence and is highly viscous on the tongue and in the swallow. A supple fruit edge like the aroma, vinous, tangy, faintly citric adjoining the hops as it presses the palate. Finish has a ripe fruit tang - mandarin - and a soft, vine clipping bitterness before it drops off with a good, well-pronounced warmth from that alcohol. It doesnt show until the end but it is definitely not shy, though not at all disturbing. Polished off, satisfied at my notes, I went down to the hostels bar to join others from around the world to enjoy litres of shitty cheap lager and maybe a few laughs. Best of the day. (50cL, 28/11/06, tasted in June 06)
Pours a syrupy brown with little head.  Has a very smooth body, and nice sweet aroma.  Flavor is a little too sweet for my taste, but would be a good desert brew perhaps.

OOOH, the munchen maibock of it all.  Hoping for something smooth and not too hard hitting since I see it is 7.2% alcohol.  Pours transparent yellow brown orange - thats 41K ohms.  Fetidness of alcohol and flavor of stalwart hops.  A little viscous in my steeler stein.  Strong, like a McEwans ale.  Finish lingers a bit with an overwelming impression, just a little too much.  Nova Paka Valdstejn is a better Heller.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Had this on a couple of occassions by the liter.  Sweet, golden bock.  Im just disappointed that I missed out on dopplebock season.  Oh well, maybe next time.  Buttery toffee flavor.  A decent go to beer while visiting the Chinesischen Turm.
Alse a good maibock but not the best. Not very spectaculair.

11/11/06: Bottle.   Amber body.  Creamy head, which quickly dissipates; lacing clings to glass.  Sweet caramel flavor with roasted nuts.Earlier Rating: 6/15/2003 Total Score: 45/10/03:  bottle.aroma of tea and wheat.  Nice caramel brown body with no lacing.  tastes include tea, malt, slight hop and honey.  nice and refreshing.  slight wheat bite as warms.

green bottle. Brown color with an off- white head.  smells a little buttery, butterscotch maybe?  a little spicy, peppers.  very malty flavor.  very smooth and light.  I would enjoy this beer more if I had more to fill a stein.  One 330mL bottle just doent cut it.  Three at a time is what this is made for!
Bottle. Not good. Thin. little head and almost no aroma. Sort of sweet. Caramel color. Some dark coffee flavor but very little. One and done.

Bottle. Poured dark amber with a huge frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing. Moderate grassy toasted malt aroma. Medium body with a watery texture. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of short duration. Earlier Rating: 4/27/2005 Total Score: 3.4Draft at brew pub. Medium amber hue with large light brown rocky head. Light malt aroma. Flavor was a light sweet with an average finish. Medium body with small alcohol bite at finish. Above average for style.

Big Munich stein of this at the Milwaukee German Beerhall,fresh distinct carmel malt aroma,full grain and carmel malt taste,fuller and thicker body then any other Maibock I have had. A glass stein and a beerhall is probaly the only way to enjoy this.
Dark orange/amber in colour with big creamy white head which disapeted quickly. Mild hoppy aroma with hint of honey. Malt flavour with mild bitter taste.

Poured a clear effervescent dark amber/copper with a fizzy off-whtie head.  Fresh aroma of grassy hops, molasses, and biscuit dough.  Taste is surprisingly hoppy, with grassy Noble hops sticking out first.  Theres s slightly sweet biscuit dough character and a dry toffee taste to it.  Finishes somewhat dry.  A little hoppier than I like in the style, but not bad.
malty and sweet.  pours with a creamy off-white head.  great finish.  good value at the price (less than $20 for 6)

[Bottled] Bronze colour, creamy head. Piney caramel aroma with a dash of alcohol. Very firm with evident grassy hops and some salty licorice. The sweetness is masked by generous amounts of malt. Medium bitterness.
Clear light amber with a solid off white head. Floral malt aroma with grass clippings and sweetness. Big body. Large malt flavor. Bit of an alcohol burn. Well balanced and clean. Quite nice.
Tasted May 26 2006, Regional Wines & Spirits Muscle Brews Tasting, Wellington, New Zealand. Deep orange colour, nutty, hoppy, very dry finish.

(Bottle 50 cl) Pours a beautiful, clear amber with a handsome, lightly creamy, off-white head. Soft aroma of malt and caramel. Nice, full body with plenty of malt. Caramel accents and a vaguely alcoholic finish. A pleasant Maibock without the sharp alcohol and bitter, hoppy finish that usually categorizes the style. 290606
Pours clear amber with fluffy off-white head. Aroma is sweet maltyness. Flavor is is spicey malt character with peppery notes. Has a dry, almost toffe like finish. Spicy beer.
Clear amber, light off-white head.  Caramel scent.  Tastes of cheap malt and caramel.

Decent dense head of fine bubbles.  Redeces to a thin foam sheen.  Decent carbonation.  Soft aroma of bready malts, some caramel and some spicy hops.  Color is a brownish orange.  Malty flavor with decent roastyness.  Little bit of bitterness at the finish.  Dry and pasty.  Spices in the flavor also.  Strange mouthfeel. Dry and pasty.  Alcohol warming at the finish.  An ok brew.
Clear amber color with a light brown head. Sweet caramel aroma. Sweet caramel flavor with some light malt.

Poured a clear amber color with an ok initial head that turned to just a rim around the top of the beer. Lacing was just above average, much better than the head would have led one to believe. The aroma was light caramel and some saaz hops. Flavor was caramel and light dark fruits, the latter unexpected based on the color and style. Nonetheless, they were light and the hops took over in the finish: light grassy saaz tones with a touch of spice to finish. Not a bad maibock at all. Alcohol a little sharp and the breadiness was underplayed (ie. not detected at all). Mouthfeel slightly sharp from the alcohol, but not cloying sweet like others have commented. Cabonation just right to wake up the taste buds. Enjoyable, although not at the top of its class.
On tap at Mayfest - Lincoln Square, Chicago.  Pours amber with an off-white head.  Malty and slightly sweet with some bitter hops on the finish.  Very drinkable.

Poured a beautiful clear bold orange color with a very very nice fluffy foamy amoung of slightly offwhite head.  Aroma is sweet and caramely with some green grape and slightly sour fruit undertones.  Flavor is very sweet, nutty, toffeeish, and caramelized sugar.  Overall, very enjoyable stronger beer perfect for a nice cool early summer night.

Bottler. Pours amber with a decent head. Aromas of malt and sweet fruit. 
Flavor is a bit alcoholic and sweet with just the right balance of malts and hops. Finsih is lasting with a touch of hoppiness. A great maibock.

On tap.  Poured a clear medium burnt amber with a well-retained cap of off-white head.  Nose was of toasty caramel and toffee, darker fruits, and some brown sugar.  Flavor was about the same... toasty caramel, brown sugar, and nuttiness were quite pleasant and smooth.  Alcohol was only present with a warming effect.  This was very good, and scarily easy to drink.
I could drink gallons of this stuff.  A great Maibock.  A great maltiness with a perfect balance of sweet flavor and warming alcohol.  Excellent

12 oz bottle.  Copper-amber, crystal clean topped by a thick off-white head.  Very persistent.  Good looking beer.  Sweet toasty malt, light caramel and a bit of brown sugar.  Malts are quite frsh tasting.  Soft sweet toasty malt flavour.  Sweet but clean throughout.  A hint of nuttiness toward the finish.  No real happiness to speak of.  Really tasty brew.  Toffeeish as it warms.  Im 4/4 on these guys this week.  All have been really tasty, this one included.

Bottled. Amber colour with big off-white head. Aroma of fruit, raisins, malts and a weak sting of alcohol. Strong malty body with hops also coming in. Weak sting of alcohol, and palate is quite "soapish" slippery. Not bad at all.

<!-- i -->Bottled<!-- /i --> (BB 10/2006)<!-- br -->
Amber brown, good off-white head. Very bready malty aroma with molasses and leafy hops. Medium-bodied, malty, quite alcoholic. European strong lager -like profile with some extra hops and caramel notes. Overall balanced although quite alcoholic.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2006 (04.15.06) One pint, 0.9 oz brown bottle from Golden Eagle, Libertyville, IL. Poured clear red amber with small white head.  Soft carbonation. Lush fruity caramel aroma.  Medium bodied beer that starts with light malt sweetness and  toasted malt/fruity/hop/toffee flavors. Finished with light hop bitterness and malty aftertaste.  Rich complex flavors.  Good aroma.  An excellent maibock.   UPDATE (04.22.06) On tap at Firkin, Libertyville, IL.  Clear amber hued beer with large white head. No discernable carbonation. Sweet malt and toffee in the nose. Medium bodied beer that starts with light malt sweetness and toffee flavor. Finished with light malt fade. Smooth and rich tasting malty beer. Delicious and definitely one of the tastiest maibocks that Ive tried thus far. Ratings stay the same for the tap and bottle versions.
Red orange color - nice head  nose tart red fruit  good hop (bitter) and smoky malt balance with sour red fruit (especially cherries)  rough texture -  aftertaste crisp but lingering

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2006 Tasted 19/05/2006.  355ml bottle from RW&S, Wellington.  
Vibrant copper (Fritha reckons amber), bright, lightly carbonated, with a disappearing off-white head.  Mild nose, but very pleasant, shows off caramel malts, spicy continental hops and a hint of lager yeast.  Sweet and sappy malts blend well with with grassy spicy hops and end in a slightly astringent finish (probably the only downfall as it just leans away from perfectly balanced).  Ive seen these Hofbrau beers on the shelf for a couple of months now and the Maibock is a very pleasant surprise (thanks Fritha).
24/05/2006. On tap at the Malthouse, Wellington. Superb biscuity notes from the toasted malt. Upped aroma and overall impression 1 point each.
Bottle. Fruity and peppery aroma. Dark copper colour. Semi-stable head. Nice peppery and malty flavours in good balance. The bitterness is a bit rough, but that also helps balance the malt.

thanks to my friend Aaron for the 1/2 L bottle.  pours crystal clear, copper amber in color with a beige head which settles to just a ring of lace.  aroma is caramel and a little bready.  but oh what great flavor for the style!  sweet caramel, bready yeast, some spice and a medium to full mouthfeel.  very enjoyable.
Smeels pretty good, caramel slightly. The flavor definitely has some caramel. Yummy and actually a little rich given the color. Hops in the finish makes this quite nice.

Draft. Clear amber body with a small off-white head. The aroma is fairly simple, sweet caramels, some floral hos. The flavor is very malty, caramel and toffee, some bitterness at the end. Medium body, slightly chewy. Very enjoyable.

Fantastic spicy aroma, sticky frothy head and perfect clear body.  Strongly malty and flavorful, with the hops in there mingling.  Some flavors here I cant quite put my finger on, but I like it.  The rest of the 6 pack will be left in the back of the fridge to age for 3 or 4 months.. I think.. or maybe just get a whole case ;)

Pours amber with a one-finger head. Aroma of caramel, German hops, and old cigars. Big caramel flavor, with a musty, lightly hoppy finish. Some of the cigar ash flavor is there, which keeps this from being one Ill come back to.

I have a completely different bottle than the one to the left.  I was thoroughly disappointed by this one. It has an amber color, but no head or lacing to speak of. Only slight carbonation. The aroma consists of some bitter hops. Taste is very disappointing. Theres only a bit of flavoring hops. Very weak body for a bock (even a Helles bock). I bought a six of this stuff. I guess Ill be chugging it some night or passing it on to friends late at night.

Pours clear light amber with an off-white head and has very lively carbonation.  Aroma is very musty malt - kind of a dusty caramel.  Starts with smooth musty caramel from the aroma with a bit of prickliness from the carbonation.  Finish is roasty sweetness with a hint of spicy hops.  A very enjoyable beer.

Not a great maibock.  Aroma is quite pleasant, with a spring freshness that is quite nice.  However, the flavor is a little sour for my taste, doesnt seem to carry that "Spring Freshness" over into the taste.  Color is a clear amber, no head when poured, dont think I will get this one again.

12oz. bottle. smells like wet dog. Pours a beautiful brick redwith a fairly viscous white head. Delicious with notes of grapes, and orange and a slightly bitter but refreshing finish of hops. A nice maibock.
Draught at the Brick.  Nice easy drinking beer.   A little bit of malt,  but mostly a rather light german style beer.  Tasty but unremarkable

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2014 Sampled on draft at the Pittsburgh location this beer poured a dark orange-brown color with a large creamy orange-white head that lingered and left decent lacing. The aroma was sweet, tangy and malty with fairly strong ripe peach, plum and cherry and a bit of artificial sugar. The flavor was very sweet and very malty artificial sugar, peach. plum, cherry, caramel and a medicinal presence underneath. Long sweet finish. Moderately full bodied and very smooth. I liked it less the more that I drank. Decent.

On draught at Brickskeller: Pours to a mostly clear light amber colored body with a small white head.  The nose is thick, sweet & chewy sugary malts, grain, dough, as well as some mild nutty/caramel malt scents.  The taste showcases the malt: chewy bread, dough, syrupy thick light malts, grains, a bit of light caramel, and just a hint of some yeast.  Medium bodied, medium carbonated, finishes thick and chewy with extended sweet malt notes.
One bottle from BOTW.  Poured a large tan head that had staying power.  Aroma of sweet malts.  Flavor of carmel,choclate,nuts and malt.  Very smooth and enjoyable drink.

$0.99 for a 16.9 oz bottle at Kenny Rd Market.  The grainy nose is what I really like about this beer.  Thick, heavy sweetness.  A great contrast to the many hoppy brews Im so fond of.  Ill have to go back tomorrow and buy a case.

Cant go wrong with this one. A bit grainy in the nose, it carries a sweetness like caramel that isnt bad. Appearance is a deep amber hue. Mouthfeel is full and round. Flavor is fruity and sweet, a bit cloying for me I thought. Overall its not a bad bit of brew.

(bottle - 500 ml) Nice copper color with an off-white head at the beginning that fizzes away quickly and doesnt leave much residue. Aroma of sweet malts, nuts, a touch of hops and some vegetables. Very sweet smelling. The flavor begins with a very malty taste with some notes of caramel, alcohol (which I didnt know was as high as it is), a good nutty flavor and a light touch of hops at the end. The aftertaste is very sweet with a light hop touch.

22oz bottle pours a nice copper color with a creamy white head.  Aromas of sweet caramel malts, nuts, some light german hops and a touch of spice.  Flavor is very malty, notes of caramel, a touch of chocolate, some spice, and a little dough..  Palate is medium bodied and smooth to drink.  A very balanced and tasty bock..  I really enjoyed this..

Bottle. Just over a pint in total volume. Brownish copper color. Very malty taste but very well balanced and smooth. Great aftertaste and could not taste the alcohol at all. I found this on sale for only a dollar each so I had to get two of them. They were both gone in the same night. I think I may have to go back for some more before they are gone.

Bottle. Really roasted grain aroma that reminds me of walking into the Sixpoint brewery when they are brewing Brownstone. Taste is nice and snappy with a great malt/hop balance. Sweet grains are predominant here. A really nice bock. Earlier Rating: 6/11/2004 Total Score: 2.8On Tap, Blind Tiger. An amber/orange color with smallish head. Aroma of caramel and spices. Taste was fruity, mostly apricots and more sweet malt. Slightly bitter and pretty well balanced. Light bodied.

Dark orange body with a thin slightly off white head. The aroma is sweet with caramel and light pears. The taste has some nice roasted nuts with some peanut brittle in the finish. There is also a hint of chocolate. This is a nice sweet change of pace. Slick mouthfeel with a little much on the carbonation.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2012 Rated on 2006.01.08 - Pours dark golden with a foamy tan head. Aroma is bready lager yeast, honey, and caramelized wort. Taste is sweet and bready, with notes of toffee and caramel. A little too sweet and simple. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and sticky with dense carbonation. Id rather have the Ayinger Maibock. 
Ar6 Ap4 Ta6 Pa3 Ov12 = 3.1

Rated on 2012.05.06 - Pours amber with a fully receding white head. Notes of bready, caramelized wort, gingerbread, herbal hops, thicky chewy malt. Full bodied with lively carbonation.
Ar7 Ap4 Ta7 Mf4 Ov13 = 3.5

Ive not had many bocks, but this has a very rich flavor and a medium to dark appearance.  A very good beer, but not quite as good as the Hofrbrauhaus Adulterator, or Doppelbock as it is called.  This Maibock is typically sold at the Hof in May only, but I was able to get it in Northern Kentucky in the bottle at a Party Source.

Smells like malty.  Looks like a nice light brownish amber color, head manages to leave reminders of itself well into the beer, nice lacing on the sides of the glass.  Lagerey, toffee, sweet, malty flavor, lighter on the palate, but doesnt disappear from the palate for what seems like hours (which is a good thing).  A really tasty beer on the lighter side of delicious (Im a dark beer guy), that Id be glad to slop down my gullet any day of the week.  In fact, a nice beer to chase a shot of whisky, wash down a slice of pizza, or enjoy on its own.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2006 Ahh a nice bock beer.  I guess I am drinking it at the wrong time of year, but it is still enjoyable.  An orange beer with tan head.  Well carbonated.  The head on mine was long lasting.  Notes of toffee, caramel, yeast, alcohol.  Complex - would probably pick out more of the flavors if I had this a few more times.  Good stuff.

Had it again - loved it just as much, noticed nutmeg in the nose, malt in the palate.
Golden copper/orange, with some creamy white head. Nose is dough. Taste is dough and honey biscuits. Nuts and caramel as well. Nice.
22os bottle. Pours a clear light brown color with a white head. Nose is light nuts with some malt and light dough. Taste is somehwat nutty, some caramel malt and light bitterness.

Pours out a light amber color with mild head.  Aroma of malt, hop, grain and some alcohol, but the alcohol was limited.  Flavor is kind of watered down, but besides that is rock solid, did notice a bit of the metallic everybody talks about but didnt think it took on too big a showing.

Poured the color of whiskey, short halflife on the head.  Aroma initially comparable to an amber or red: fairly malty.  Like others, I noticed a metallic flavor initially, when coldest.  Also a bitter flavor like some stouts.  These resolved into a smooth malt and hop flavor and by the time I was at the bottom of the glass and the beer was nearly room temp, I tasted hints of clover honey, much like the Hofbrau Munchen Original.  Not terrible or undrinkable, but the only reason Id buy this again is for a gift or hosting a beer tasting.

Orange amber with a good sized head.  Aroma is sweet malt and a subtle fruit aroma  of bananas and raisins.  Flavor is sweet malt up front with a nice hops and alcohol backbone.  Medium bodied with very light carbonation.  The biggest strike against this one was a metallic taste when this was cold but that vanished as it warmed.  Not as hoppy as Im used to in a Maibock but still very good.
light orange with no head.aroma and flavor were of sweet malts.pretty boring overall.

caramel, with grains aroma.  body is copper, with no real head, looks like watery soda.  taste is mettalic, with a
slight hint of alcohol along with some caramel.
Has a malty aroma and pours a golden color with a white head.  Starts with a malty flavor and balances out with a nice hoppiness.  Has a medium body and aftertaste.
Bottle. Tastes very alcoholic, bitter, slightly malty (nutty?), and sweet. Smells like bananas and alcohol. I dont have much experience with bocks yet, but I like it.

A light-amber brew. Alcohol and apple in the aroma. Remote hints of butterscotch. Hints of toffee and butterscotch in the initial flavor. Gets bitterer and a bit roasted to the finish. Alcohols starts to dominate. Medium to full, dry.

It has a refreshing sweet smell. There is also traces of malt and fruit in the nose. Pours out light reddish or orange with a reasonable white head. Tastes of sweet hops and malt. Overall a good bock.

This pours a clear deep amber body that sits under a dense off white head.
Fruity malt aroma.
Malty and very smooth.  Very well done and Ill buy this again if I see it.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2010 Pours a light orange with a thin sticky white head and nice lace.  Aroma is extremely malty- lots of vienna and light munich malts.  Lots of bready malts, nuts, and sweet caramel.  Flavor is big sweet and malty with some hops in the aftertaste.  Extremely smooth- not harsh or cloying.
Sweet and mlaty nose, some caramel, slight note of alcohol. Amber colored, served in a nice HB stein. Lovely sweet malt flavor, ends light hoppy. Good one.
Bottled. Light amber coloured, with a huge off-white head. Nose of sweet malt, fruit and yeast. It has a sweet soft flavor, with notes of roasted malt, caramel and fruit.

Clear bright amber-copper color with a nice foamy lasting off white head that leaves some lacing in my glass. Has a sweet fruity and nutty aroma. Sweet and malty roasty caramel, honey flavors that has a sweet lasting finish, medium body with a slick and smooth mouthfeel, alcohol well hidden, very nice.
Poured a bright candy red with an initially towering inferno of bubbles that settled into a nice cushion of a head.  Light caramel aroma.  Sugary caramel flavors, but disappointingly flat-feeling..

Bottled. Light herbal, grain and a hint of apple in the aroma. Amber color, off-white head, fair lace. Light sweet, bitter, apple in the flavor as well, bit of butter and even some roastiness althought its a helles, quite alcoholic. Another style I must stop rating. Theres just nothing going on for me in maibock.

Bottled: Served by Jacob @ Ølbaren in stein, but pours a light amber colour. Has a dense off white head. Berries, malt and has some undefined freshness in the aroma. Malt, sweetness, fruit and alcohol in the flavour. Some light caramel notes. Is grassy and light alcoholdense in the end. Gives a light warmth on the lips. Quite refreshing.

Starts off very good with some coffee and caramel flavors. The finish dropped down to a metallic, musty thing that definitely lost points for me. If the start carried through, this would be a top beer.

Discount Liquors, Milwaukee, WI. - 500 ml bottle. Purs a bright orange with a decent sized, sticky mocha colored head. Fresh lake water aroma with some caramel accents. Flavor is somewhat mellow and subdued for a bock. Hints of molasses, caramel and a wee bit of alcohol, but it is hidden rather well for 7.2%. Very easy drinking bock. Mouthfel is rather thick and creamy. Average, inching toward above average bock.

Bottled.
Clear orange coloured with a creamy off white head.
Sweet malty aroma with lots of caramel and notes of fruits.
Sweet flavour of dark bread with notes of malts and an OK hoppy finish.

Not my favorite style to begin with, I should forewarn.  Copper brown, decent but fading head.  Aroma was of candied brocolli, that combination of malt and hops that I just dont care for.  Flavor was sweet, with more brocolli and some sour bread.  Not my thing.  It did get better as it warmed, reducing the sour note and bringing out some caramel.  But just not my bag.
In the bottle at the Huber Haus. Great aroma of straw and caramel. Light Amber in color with an off-white head. Great lacing. Finish is sweet.
bottled, amber w/ off white head. malt aroma w/ notes of toffee. medium bodied.
A good example of this style- firm malt base and caramel and malt flavors finish dry and smooth.

Draught at the Hofbrauhaus in Las Vegas.
Pours a medium copper with great head and lacing. Sweet malt nose. Balanced malt flavor with a light hop bite. Crisp and refreshing. Good bock.

(on bottle-cheers joss) Dark Abricot colour, white head, fast gone though. Aroma of alcohol and a hint of candid rubarb and vanilla. Hard lashing carbonation and a tangy bitterness, in both taste and finish, makes it an agreeable swilldrink. Now let´s watch some fussball.

Nice clear copper with a thick off-white head. Aroma of floral hops, grain, some grass, caramel and smoke. Flavor has notes of toasted grain, toffee, caramel, dark fruits, a good dose of hops with a nice backdrop of smoke. Pleasantly sweet, some bitterness in there too. Medium, silky smooth body with subtle carbonation - coats the mouth very nicely. Great head retention. A multi-dimensional brew, I recommend it.

Light pleasant nose, tawny pale brown, tall fluffy head. Sweet caramelly malt taste and aroma. A celery-like flavor in the middle with an oaky drying finsih. Medium body, creamy mouth feel. Good, classy beer.
Very good.  Metallic aroma at first pour was off-puting, but I say that about a lot of German lagers.  Tastes like an extra thick oktoberfest, with less bittering hops.  Fine, fine lager overall.

Medium frothy head - medium lasting. Nice copper color, medium carbonation. Band aid medium malt nose. Kind of veggie taste first, followed a nice mellow malt tones and some wooden ones too. Oily in texture.
Good cross behind double bock and amber. Malty aroma from the get go. Malty but not overwhelming. Clean finish no aftertaste. Wish the actual hofbrauhouse served this beer regularly
Very malty, a bit sweet, but overall a good beer. Nice copper color, good head. I couldnt detect much of an alcohol bite, that was nice for me. Will drink again.

Copper amber color. Medium to large sized head. Aroma is caramel, toffee and sweet. A medium bodied bock. Malts are fairly sweet, lots of toffee and caramel flavors. Fairly complex malt flavors. Touch of an alcohol bite. Smooth taste. Nice bock, there is a lot of different malt flavors going on here. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is crisp and dry. Aftertaste is slightly sweet with a touch of malt.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2005 Im surprised at the low score also.  I really enjoyed it.  Poured light amber with a thin whte head.  Aroma had gin and tonic, caramel malts, brown sugar, honey and cider.  Taste is very pleasant with a good cider and gin and tonic feel throughout.  Very nicely done.

17 oz. brown, tall bottle. Cryptic date code on back label, but its a fresh sample. Poured out a definite orange color, with a thin, sticky white head.
Left a decent lacing down the sides of the glass. Aromas are of some fruity esters, sweet malts, yeasty bread, slight dry biscuit notes also. Medium mouthfeel. Dry finish to it. Decent Maibock overall.

I am suprised at the relatively low score for this brew.  Absolutely fantastic canvas for malt lovers everywhere.  This stuff just screams munich brew.  Nice color, flavor, aroma, and texture.  A true showcase of maltsters.  I should probably be a little more technical, but I am buzzed and this stuff is great.

Clear sparkling orange,  creamy off white head.  Soft nose of sweet toffee and toast, with underlying tones of breadiness and grassiness.  The light sweet malt and flowery German hops blend nicely for near perfect balance.   Medium to full bodied, light carbonation, bittersweet, caramel grassy finish.  A nice session Maibock if there is such a thing...

UPDATED: APR 25, 2005 Pours an orange/crimson color. Not alot of head. Aroma is mostly malty with some yeast being present as well. Feels quite thick going down. Nice malty character. Some sweetness. A little taste of yeast. Some hoppy bitterness in the finish. Slight hint of alcohol as well. Good flavors that are well blended.

Clean aroma, medium-toasty malt, spicy noble hops.  Crystal clear copper color, mesmerizing trails of swirling bubbles lead up to a thick off-white head.  Bready malt flavor balances out spicy and herbal hops, just a hint of canned corn.  Sweet malt up front transitions into hop bitterness in the finish.  Medium body, crisp but not a lawnmower beer.  Clean and nicely balanced.
Very nice amber color with a small off-white head. Sweet and spicy cinnamon, sugar, malt, and honey aroma. Nice sweet candy sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, peach, honey and bread flavors. Fairly crisp feel.

Strikingly beautiful crystal clear amber color with a small off-white head. The aroma and flavor hint at cinnamon, bread, slight alcohol, and cherry. The feel was rather crisp, not too thin...wet coating finish. Nice.
Aroma is a syrupy sweet but not necessarily in a good way. Flavor is dusty and astringent. Either this brew is overrated or I got an old bottle. No good.

Amber color with a large white head.  Aroma of sweet malt with a hint of hops.  Sweet malt continues and dominates the flavor with a mild hop finish.  Lots of flavor.  Smooth, easy to drink. Alcohol is present but not overly so.
Bottle. Rich amber beer with a big off-white head. Caramel flavor. Light body, easy to drink. Grassy, spicey aroma. Just not enough.
Bottle. Amber colour with a medium white head. Sweet light hay malty aroma and a sweet malty caramel taste. Medium body and a sweet finish.

a nice sweet aroma, hints of vanilla and hops.  body is amber/copper with a cream colored head.  very tasty brew, featuring caramel malts with vanilla highlights and a smooth citrusy hop tail.  this was an excellent medium bodied bock.

(bottle) red/copper colour with medium frothy off-white head. The aroma is very caramellish with malts and well blended aromatic hops. The taste is also malty with caramel, but far away from being sweet, rounded up with hops and hints of vanilla and nuts. A smooth, not too alcoholic Maibock.
Appearance: Dark amber with a big head. Smells of sweet malts. Flavos is sweet maltiness and a bit of candy-funkiness. Not overly impressed.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2016  Bottle: Dark amber, almost ruby-red, coloured, firm yellowish foam; highly aromatic malty nose with some tinge of candy; fll, creamy body; very soft and extremely well rounded; nutty flavour, ending in a distinctive but harmonic bitterness; this Maibock is very,very moreish.......

From the bottle it produces a large head with plenty of staying power. A very nice deep, amber color.  I get some hops in the aroma, not a whole bunch of malt, really a balance.  The taste is good, a bit over-carbonated, perhaps.  The first of this style that Ive rated.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2005 Keith-Red color with a white head that stays thin for a good time.  Malty aroma matches the malty and sweet flavor.  Caramel hints add to the sweetness that stays in the mouth a while.Earlier Rating: 6/26/2004 Total Score: 2.5Medium body and an orange color.  Malty but not as much of a bock as I hoped for.  7.2% ABV and a nice balnce makes this a pleasent beer though.
Dark golden colour with a beige head. Malty aroma with a caramel sweetness. The flavor also has a caramel sweetness with lots of alcohol in the finish.
Amber color. Malty aroma with some corn; light. Strong alcohol, strong bitterness, strong caramel. Deadly boring.
An amber beer with a disappearing orange head. The aroma is sweet with notes of caramel, peach, and alcohol. The flavor is sweet and quite dry with notes of caramel and lots of alcohol.
Amber color with a beige head. The taste is a sweet malty body with slight caramel and light alcohol notes.

Bottled. Clear amber colour. Vivid, bubbly head, which is quite big at first, but diminishes rather quickly to nothing. Flowery, malty aroma. Very malty, pretty sweet taste. Slightly alcoholic. A bit of chocolate and butter in the malty finish. One of the better Maibocks.

Started off great and then everything went progressively downhill.  Looked beautiful in my .5 L glass boot - fizzy, amber, 1" orange head.  Smelled sweet, malty and yeasty.  The first sip was when things started to unravel - alcohol not well hidden at all.  Rich malt, barley-grain taste complimented by the expected wheat notes.  Nearing the end of the beer, the alcohol seemed drawn apart and even more intrusive.  Last 25% of the beer was sticky and separated; astringent.  The sweetness became overbearing.  On the bottle, Hofbrau said that this was the first Maibock ever brewed in the world.  Im glad there have been significant improvements to the Maibock category since Hofbrau introduced this concoction.
Straight 7/10, 3.5/5 material.  All that youd except in a German bock, down to the standard malty burn.

Light brangy hue with light beige head sweet palate dry oily palate sweet malty aroma hoppy and slightly acidic could gbe hard to finish whole bottle quite cloying there is a slight nutty background flavour

I like my bock and look forward to the spring in Cincinnati when it use to flow freely from every establishment worth frequenting. This particular Maibock was malty but it didnt kick me in the head like I would have liked it to. Overall it was drinkable and smooth. But I would have ordered the usual had I wanted smooth. I still look forward to having it this spring again.
Bottled. Enjoyed o the way back from the Burton beer festival. Deep amber, sweet notes in the bready nose, some chewy malt with a hinted bitter finish.

This is a decent full-bodied maibock with plenty of sweet malty flavoring and a mild hopping.  It poured an almost brown orange color with a fizzy off-white head that dissipated quickly.  Very smooth to drink with a nice bitter-sweet finish.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is clear medium amber. Aroma is moderately malty (bread, cookie), moderately hoppy (flowers). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter, grainy. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Sourish and terribly grainy aftertaste ruins the decent aroma. Poor, or poor sample?

Bright glowing orange color with a big, fluffy head. Really quite beautiful. Nose is malty, slightly dusty with a bready yeast character. Rather dry for a bock with a good, solid flavor. Not overly complex but really smooth and drinkable.Light to medium bodied with just the right amount of carbonation.  I have a feeling that at 7.2% ABV this stuff might sneak up on you.

500 ml bottle.  Clear medium amber, fluffy decaying head.  Big malty-caramel aroma, touch of rum and vanilla, bready-yeasty.  Bready in the body as well, with a bit of orange, little hoppiness.  Nice body.  More citrusy than most bocks, medium body...a little thinner than usual for the style but highly drinkable.
Clear amber body, puffy white head.  Bready aroma.  Buttery wheat bread malt sweetness, slightly citric and stemmy hops.  The mouthfeel is noticably over-carbonated.
If anything, the greatest disappointment is in appearance.  The taste is appropriate for a maibock (as opposed to traditional bocks).  Reasonable if unremarkable.

Ruby/orange color,tall white head that lasted fo a nice long time then faded to a nice lace.malty sweet aroma with a little fruit possibly citrus and a mild bread dough smell coming through as well.Nice malty taste with a mild caramelish flavor and a mild hop presence.The brew seems to have an almost creamy or maybe its medium full feel to it,but over all its very smooth and easy drinking.I like this brew much better then some of the American versions of the Maibock style.Thanks to Jpdipso for sending a another nice one my way.Earlier Rating: 7/9/2003 Total Score: 4.1Very nice amber color,or maybe it's mahogany.Tall light tan head.Malty sweet aroma,caramel,mild spice to it,but you have to look for it but it is there.Malty taste with a slight sweetness,caramel again and a mild hop presence.Theres a pretty decent after taste that is mildly bitter malty and the hops give a nice touch of bitterness at the very end.The alcohol is mostly hidden until the end when you can detect it in a mild amount that doesn't make you wince.The feel isin the medium range just right IMO.This is a great brew and worth having a few more around.

Clear amber body with an average sized slightly white head.  Aroma is nicely malty and bready with mild spicyness and very modest hops presence. The flavor is malty, lightly sweet, and a little bready.  Finish is very lightly dry.  Id say this is enjoyable but not remarkable.

Well, I am pretty sure that this is the one that I had. Wow, let me tell you this was pretty cool. Had it at this german restauraunt in Gibson City. Very cool atmosphere and stuff. So if you are cruising down I-75 and you pass PAXTON Illinois exit, it is well worth the 15 min detour. NOW FOR THE BEER: Dark orange nose is crisp and full of malts with a nice filling of hops. The flavour is muted with malts and some hops. Finishes bitter. Man, this stuff was pretty good. Easily drinkable and somewhat wattery?
Darker golden color, tan head. Smells malty, tastes malty and sweet with just a little hop presence. Too sweet for my taste.

Caramel malty-sweetish aroma with hops. Malts are a little roasted. Clear, amber coloured with a thin lasting off-white head. Taste is balanced, a little hoppy and again those caramel malts. Quite sweet with just a little bitterness. Smooth palate. I can drink this all day.
Orange/amber coloured, medium head. Malty, bit hoppy aroma. Sweet malty, bit metallic flavour.

Deep orange.  Nose has lots of malts, plenty of caramel, hops noticeable.  Very good malts in the flavor, caramel and sweetness predominate, good bitterness at end, mild fruitiness as well.  Good stuff.
Clear orange-brown color, medium off-white head. Aroma of amber malts, hops, typical german. Taste is caramel, malty, bit sweet, bit sharp metallic, some vinegar. Bit dry and sticky palate.

The beer says it is Hofbrau Maibock, American label. Rusty orange/peach colored beer. Thin offwhite head. Smells sweet and malty, syrupy smell almost. Plum, dates, something here. Great flavor for a German beer. Caramel/toffee flavor as well. Leading to a dry bitter finish. Sweet flavor. Not too bad.

Pours a clear gold/reddish color with a very small white head.  Very good lacing.  Aroma is very malty with some alcohol notes.  Flavor is like that of walking through a brewery.  Very "fresh."  Some hop bitterness in there as well.  Body is medium with a dry finish.

Pours with a large creamy head. Aroma is of creamed corn. Flavor is of corn, lightly toasted malt and a small bit of caramel/toffee. Alcohol fumes up in the finish a bit when warmer. The corn flavor is a bit much even though I seem to be the only one to taste it, but its still tasty.
Draught in Munich. Clear copper brown, off-white head. Very clean and intense aroma of toasted and caramel malt. Smooth malty mouthfeel, well balanced.

Crystal clear amber with large off-white foam.  Aroma is medium sweet, strong caramel/toffee, some alcohol.  Taste is mild sweet, earthy, toffee, caramel, somewhat fruity, finishing medicinal alcohol and grainy.  Medium body with light stickiness.

Damn this is one fine looking beer! Clear sparkling amber body topped by a luxurious pillowy off-white head that leaves big weeping sheets of lacing. Aroma is mildly sweet with a sour malt and alcohol aroma. The flavor is also mildly sweet with a nice bit of toffee and a tad bit of bitterness towards the end. The body is medium with a little alcohol bite. I really like this one and could imagine knocking a few of these back!

This beer poured a bright orange with a large white head.  The aroma was bready and the taste was malty.  The finish was somewhat sweet and made me want more.  This was a great beer and one worth trying.  One of the best in the style.

One of three favorite bottled Maibocks (along with Einbacker and Capital, now the Ayinger stopped making theirs) I always buy a couple every year. Now on to my rating...Nice coppery hue with fading frothy off-white head and above average lace. The aroma is heavy caramel, light sage, light aromatic and noble hops, hazelnut, and dusty yeast esters. The taste is malty with caramel, sweet bread, and toffee tones. Additional undertones of currents, spice, and mild Saaz hops detected. The finish displays a nutty, vanilla and dusty character. The mouthfeel is soft but not flat, the alcohol is extremely well hidden in this brew. Underrated IMO, this is the best brew made by Hofbrauhaus Munchen. Try some fresh this March.

On draught at the Bier Stube. Bright orange color, with a small white head. Taste is sticky sweet with a yeasty and caramel flavor. Alcohol is well hidden. I didn't think I liked Maibocks -- this one proved me wrong.
Copper body with white head.  Nose had hints of caramel sweetness and maybe some grape and spice.  Flavor was subtly sweet with a  little sour edge.

I thought I had something unique when I picked this bottle up, but I failed to note the "HB" logo on the label.  But, I was pleasantly rewarded!  This is my new favorite maibock.  Clean copper body with a thin off-white head.  Bready malt and caramel aroma.  Flavor really shines: a variety of bready flavors, ranging from dry toast to sweeter malts, caramel, and toffee.  Nice complexity.  Hard to believe this is 7.2% ABV.  Smooth and delicious.
Very pleasant to drink. Nice creamy white head.  Malty. Brown in color. Excellent maibock. Had it on tap at a friends house. Very good.

Beautiful orange color. Heavy malty apricot aroma. Sweetish flavor with some hopbitterness. Very fruity (apricot and blackcurrant). Some alcohol, that is overpowered  by the heavy maltiness. Lovely maibock, one of the better of its kind.
Nice amber color with a white head. Big malt nose. Smooth well rounded malt with a touch of bitternes. Great maibock
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: This bottle reads "Product of Germany" but it is in English so I assume this is the beer. Pours a brownish-amber color with a medium light beige head. Fair lacing. Aroma of lightly roasted malt. Light to medium-bodied and rather smooth, it has a tart flavor with a strong malt backbone. The finish is a toasty and hoppy. Overall an easy-drinking beer but an average one.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2007 This ones pretty good, but a tad watery compared to the European Maibocks. Still, Id recommend this to anyone interested in that style of brew. - -  Im adding to this due to my currently sitting at the Newport H-haus with a maibock in  my hand... the finish to this one is a bit strange, a burnt caramel sharpness. Still a good beer, though.

Grainy, granola malt aroma that left me wanting more. Good label, light orange beer with tan pithy head. Grain, over a tinny bock with medium dark syrup sweetness. Finish is sharply bitter and an endurance affair. Not for the alcopop crowd.
Bronze color with a big head. Malt aroma. Flavor is sweet, bready, caramel. Pretty drinkable

in a clever ruse of camouflage, it tries to conceal itself among any ambient butterscotch or brassy hues,  shiny as a polished skeleton key. lager- fresh head is quick to respond to your attention, but  just  temporarily. soft vanilla orange aroma, bready-- a touch of alcohol and playdoh.  pardon me for being so gauche as to consider lucre in these exalted halls of epicurean purity, but at a buck seventy a pint, this is a dandy happy hour quaffer.  carbonation sparkles at the edges of the tongue, but flows gently over the middle. persuasive malty structure, tea flavor with constrained bitterness, amped with vanilla wafer sweetness and the authority of deputized alcohol.
the bottle reads amber, and that's what it was.  sort of malty, and very strong flavor.  nutty; hard to decide if it was sweet or bitter!  not bad.

Crystal clear deep gold/light amber body w/ a frothy off white head.  Malty munich aromas as well as toasty and bready notes; no hop aroma or fruitiness.  Malt is dominant at first with Munich malt and toasty(Vienna) flavors, but hop flavor is more pronounced in bitterness than expected for a Maibock, but pretty well evenly balanced overall.  Hop flavor and bitterness are in the finish and aftertaste.  Moderately carbonated w/ a nice medium body and smooth texture but the alcohol seems a little lower than expected.  I was expecting more of a malt based taste and finish, but a little too well balanced for my taste.  IMHO, it should be more malty in balance and finish, but a good beer nonetheless.
Aroma of malt sweetness and a little spicy hop. Pours a nice deep copper color with a quickly diminishing head. Malt flavor dominates but it is still well balanced for a maibock.
Nice hoppy Maibock.  Sweet malty flavor balanced with a good dose of bitterness.  Blond amber hue, aroma suggests a sweet beer.  Best if sampled in Munich.
Cloudy,small head, orangish color.  Malty sweet.  Slight notes of spices, but I'll be darn if I can pick them out.  Malt covered any hops notes.  Good Maibock.
Eh, I liked it.  Been awhile since I've had one, though.  Probably would rate it better, too.

Oh, how well do I remember my visit to Munichs Hofbrau!  It was so difficult to find a seat, but a nice trio of Americans slid over in the booth and allowed us to share the late afternoon meal with them.  The food and beer were just slightly less than expectations, but the overall experience (at the bottom of my liter of beer) was excellent.  My daughter, two years old at the time, loved the large dough pretzels and the oomp-pah band.  Well, here is my first visit back to the Hofbrau, with a much different beer.  Caramel color and aroma, with a nice head, and a tongue-coating but somewhat flat palate, this beer is rich enough and flavorful enough (caramel and dried fruit, without any negative flavors) to rank as a very enjoyable beer, though again I had a slightly-less-than-expectations experience due to the mouthfeel that comes out a bit sweetly dead, though it does have an oily richness to it.  Either experience (the Hofbrau or the Maibock) is worth having at least once.  Back label stamped: 19.02.03, 0849 [batch number presumably].
UPDATED: MAY 10, 2003 Amber darkcolor; small head with everlasting lace; grassy nose; carmelly flavor with overwhelimng sweetness.  Very nice.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Amber-gold.  Caramel and hay in the nose. Mmm... very nice, caramel malts, dry grassy hops, and even a hint of sugar cookie. The sweet/sour/nutty coating on my tastebuds alternates on sips.

Nutty brown appearance and an initial burst of sweetness that hits you hard.Far from a subtle beer this is one you either love or hate.Full of body it should have a note on the label-please treat me with respect.Once you get into you realise it is more complex than you originally thought beneath the sweetnes there are some subtle secondary tastes. I subscribe the group that loves it although i can understand that it may not be everyones taste.
Copper with a nice fluffy off white head. caramel malt aroma.  Taste is very malty, and caramel-toffeeish, finish is sweet, perhaps a little overbearingly sweet. all in all a pretty solid beer

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 This beer has a small initial head that is off-white in color with good lacing. The body is a clear amber color. It initially tasted light then built to a small bitterness, something I don't particularly like in my beers. But then I am spoiled by Andechs! Im Himmel gibt es Keine bier darum trinken vir es hier! (In heaven there is no beer that is why we drink it here!)

This leaned way too far into high fructose corn syrup territory for me.  Yes, there are some very nice malts here - almost complex - sweetness of grapes along with spices and some very subtle nuts and roastyness.  It's just the finish that bothers me - all sugar and not enough to dry it out.
Very clear copper color with good head.  Lots of sweet malt in the aroma and body.  Could use more balance though.  The finish is a touch sticky.
Malt galore! Great bock with a perfect fruity/winey taste to it. Dark in color and drinks well.
Rich, huge aroma - malt, brandy, wine, tad earthy.  Similar but less pronounced flavour.  Good dose of vanilla.  A bit watery, kinda metallic.

Mmmm.  Wake up and smell the Mai-Bock.  Tremendous fluffy head over fine copper.  Deep rich malt aroma.  Wonderful sweet malt, and as you swallow, youll find alcohol tingling the roof of your mouth, wafting through your nose and warming your chest.  What a great example of this style.
Very nice color, alittle bit of somked after taste,a very nice beer all around
Very clear, orange.  Slight aroma of spice, and citrus.  Nice body, rich, with a hint of sweetness, and caramel.  A very good bock beer.

Light bourbon clear under a medium shortish lasting yellow head. Light fruity sappy hops together with faint hints of malt and roasted/smoked caramel. Medium thin smooth crisp clean body. Flavour mirrors aroma quite nicely plus added medium bitter hops for balance. Smooth faint fruity and dry bitter finish and aftertaste. Nice!

Reddish-orange in color, with a good head and lace. Strong malt smell. Damn...the malt kicked me right in the teeth. That is the strongest malt taste Ive ever had. Theres a tangy flavor that is powerful as well, particularly as the beer warms. Bitter and aciding at the end. An average beer.
Slight, tart, and fruity aroma.  Deep copper colored liquid.  Explosive nutty tartness on sipping.  Water like texture.

Crystal-clear amber color with generous off-white head--intricate latticework lace...Aroma of rich malt with a yeasty tang.  Full body is felt immediately, even before the mellow balanced flavors. Here malt sweetness, acidic tang and hoppy dryness all share the stage. Carbonation is moderate and appropriate. Finish similarly balanced and extremely smooth. Very quaffable stuff--great buoyancy of elements on a very substantive base. No single quality stands out here...a little of this...a little of that...but all good...

This was an above average bottled Maibock.  It would be better fresh, but Im sure you already know that.  It wasnt too sweet or malty.  I wouldnt say it was bland, but Ive had better.  A good overall choice for a Maibock though.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2006 Rerate from the bottle: bronze body with a small white head. Nose is malty and sweet with light caramel, and some grassy hops. Taste is also malty and sweet with a touch of caramel, light hops, some grass, and dried fruit. Body is medium with a bubbly feel to it. Finishes with more malt and caramel, faint grassy notes, and light Euro hops. Original rating was a 3.2.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2003 How do they get the goat on the label to hold a stein when everybody knows goats don't have opposable thumbs?!  A light, sourish/sweetish, copper-colored maibock beer that won't be confused with a doppelbock anytime soon.  Could drink more than one.  Very very malty and caremelly sweet with a hint of alcohol.  Nice toffee aroma, too.
Lovely amber almond in color and sports a sweet rich aroma that is a bit yeasty. The body is light, but deep with malt flavors that linger on the palette. A fine beer I must say.

Good head starts off the pour.  A nice aroma of chestnuts and malt.  An intersting, subtle flavor and texture.  A bit sour on the top of the palate, with acidic textures on the side of the tongue.  Full flavor malt gives this beer a great body.  This is a quality beer that should be tried.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2004 Best before 02-3-03 Copper color liquid sitting atop a dense foam.  Abundant toasty, nutty, caramel malt.  A mixture of hay/dung smell, unlike the familiar Belgian barnyard traits, takes the aroma above and beyond traditional Maibock boundaries.  Hops are present, yet very subdued.  Acidic twang rides the palate before caramel and nuts gain full control.  Bountiful carbonation leads me to believe this beer is alive and well.  Malt accented, but fairly simplistic.

text: Orange-amber colored, with light carbonation and a lingering head.  Aroma is mostly dark grain, nutty, maybe a little wet cardboard (now I understand people mean when theyve mentioned that)  Fairly drinkable, but far from exciting.
Light amber color, with a head leading to nice lace.  Slight toast and toffee flavors.  A generally nondisagreeablr brew.
Malty, yes, but kind of light. Lacks the depth of malt flavors I want out of a lager; might as well be drinking an Amstel.
Nice malty bock, with lots of sweet flavors but smooth enough to drink quite a lot of it.
Love the maltyness of this brew. A tad sweet but it is afterall a Mai Bock. Great to wash down a juicy steak!
UPDATED: AUG 3, 2003 Very very nice. As malty as is possible, I do believe. Not too sweet, but mighty close.

mmm, wonderfully toasty and toffeeish.
